msContents.summary: The Vajrāvalī, also known as Vajrāvalī nāma Maṇḍalopāyikā is a ritual compendium compiled by the famous abbot of Vikramaśila monastery, Abhayākaragupta (late 11th–early 12th century CE). It is one of the largest works of tantric Buddhism that deals exhaustively with the various rituals and ceremonies to be performed within a monastic compound (Mori 2009: 1). According to the colophon, this manuscript was written in 1429 CE at Pātan in the famous Golden Monastery (hiraṇyavarṇavihāra) by the Buddhist monk Jivayībhadra, at the beginning of king Jayayakṣamalla 's reign (1428-1482 CE).

msItem.title: Vajrāvalī
Vajrāvalī nāma Maṇḍalopāyikā
msItem.incipit: [1v1] vande śrīkuliśeśvaraṃ smarata re mārā bhavāreḥ padaṃ krodhā dhāvata dikṣu maṅgalagiro gāyantu vajrāṅganāḥ | śrīmadvajrabhṛto mahimni jaga[1v2]d ādhātuṃ mahāmaṇḍale niṣpratyām ihābhayasya mahasā va%jrāvalī mīlatu ||
msItem.explicit: [126r1] ghaṇṭālakṣaṇādividhiḥ || @ || iti paramamunīnāṃ vāgudandhaty agādhe śrutim api na prarīyuḥ ke pi ke pi plavante | sakṛpamatimahimnāsmābhir antarnimajjyāmṛta[126r2]m idam upanīta prītaye te bhujandāḥ || sukṛtam uditam uccair jyo%tin antarjvalad yan prasṛtam iha mahimnām ākasyāśu trābhyā | vilasantu mama vajrapreyasīsa¦[126r3]rmadhāmni trijagadabhayabhartur maṇḍale viśvamarttaḥ
msItem.finalRubric: [126r3] mahāpa¦%ditā abhayākaraguptaviracitā vajrāvalī nāma maṇḍalopāyikā samāptaḥ ||
msItem.colophon: [126r3] ye dharmā [126r4] hetu-prabhavā hetun teṣā tathāgato jo ṇirodha evāṃdī mahā%śramanaḥ || śrīyo 'stu ḥ samvat 549 bhādrapada śuklaḥ pañcamyā yā tithau viśāṣa¦[126r5]nakṣatre ḥ śaṇicaravāśureḥ -4- rājādhirā japrarameśva¦%rasya śrīśrīśrī jayajakṣamaladevasya vijayarāje ḥ likhita śrī māṇigalake ḥ utravi¦[126r6]hāre ḥ srīharṇṇavarṇṇamahāvihārāvasthitaḥ bhikṣu ^ srījivayībhadreṇa svahastena likhitaṃm iti ḥ jathā dṛṣṭa -1- ta thā likhita lekhināsti do.ayāmī ḥ śubham astu || [126v1] oṃ namo buddhāya ||

supportDesc.foliation: Nepālākṣarā letter numbers, mid-left margin, verso.
supportDesc.condition: Complete, in relatively good condition, often worm-eaten. Several modern restorations. The writing is sometimes faded. Folio 59 verso and 96 verso are stained. The first and last pages are worn out.

layout.p:
6 lines per page, approximately 64 akṣaras per line. 4
1

Some puṣpikās, daṇdas and visargas are highlighted in red. Both in the final rubric and the colophon, a visarga with a red highlight in the middle is seemingly employed as a sort of daṇḍa (in the transcription, it is rendered as an isolated visarga).
layout.stringHole: One string hole, approximately in the middle of a blank space 2 to 2.50 cm wide.

handNote.desc: Hooked Nepālākṣarā script in black ink.
handNote.p: Note: In some cases, the anusvāra is represented by a particular sign of two small circles which can be sometimes confused with visarga. Normally the anusvāra is located very close to the upper horizontal line of each character and is therefore very difficult to determine. [...] The letter r before consonants is quite often dropped, as such is also the case with the anusvāra. A fair amount of confusion between short and long vowels occurs in many places. The vowel a is sometimes inserted between two consonants in certain words (e. g. pra becomes para; atma becomes atama). The scribe often confuses the following letters: sa/śa/ṣa, na/ṇa, hya/ha, dya/da. Some words are always spelled wrongly: viseṣa becomes viśiṣa, tṛtīyam becomes tṛtiyam, tiryak becomes triryak (Mori 2009: 32). Some visargas are to be understood as daṇḍas (see the transcription of the colophon).

additions.p: Folio 1 recto, first column, in Nepālākṣarā characters:
Folio 1 recto, second column, in Nepālākṣarā characters:
Folio 126 verso, first column, invocation to the triratna in Nepālākṣarā characters:

list.item: āṃthabhra $ namo budhāya, namo dharmāya, namo saṃghāyaḥ ||

additions.head: Marginalia

item.marginalia: Marginal annotations by different hands in Nepālākṣarā and hooked Nepālākṣarā scripts (see for instance folios 22r, 64r7, 114v and 115r).

history.origin: 549 Nepāla Saṃvat / Saturday, September 3rd 1429 CE (Petech 1984: 168-9). Nepāl Pātan.
history.provenance: Bought by Dr. D. Wright Wright, Daniel in 1873-6.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
